data.title: Your Ultimate New York City Playlist: 15 Iconic Songs About NYC
data.meta_description: Rock out to the most iconic songs about NYC on our ultimate playlist to honor the greatest city in the world!
data.text:
NYC has been home to creatives forever, so itâ€™s no wonder poets, artists and musicians find it so inspirational. From itâ€™s fascinating history to endless opportunities, NYCâ€™s allure is undeniable.

In fact, NYC is the most sung about city in music, reported Forbes in 2019. New York has been featured in lyrics across 161 charting songs, with London just behind us.

So weâ€™ve decided to compile some of the most iconic songs about NYC for you to jam out to when youâ€™re feeling giddy off the NYC spirit. Listen along here! ğŸ‘‡

1. â€œNew York, New York,â€ Frank Sinatra

Would it really be a list of iconic songs about New York without this classic by Frank Sinatra? This tune gained popularity on Frank Sinatraâ€™s 1980 album Trilogy: Past Present Future. Itâ€™s so famous it has even become the New York Yankees victory song!

2. â€œEmpire State of Mind,â€ Jay-Z Ft. Alicia Keys

Played in every bar and club in NYC, Jay-Zâ€™s â€œEmpire State of Mindâ€ simply never gets old. As a matter of fact, the track is actually one of Jay-Zâ€™s most successful singles, according to Genius and actually nods to Billy Joelâ€™s â€œNew York State of Mind,â€ and Nasâ€™ â€œN.Y. State of Mind.â€

3. â€œNo Sleep Till Brooklyn,â€ the Beastie Boys

New York-born band, the Beastie Boys, wrote this popular track about their tiring time on tour, anticipating their arrival home.

4. â€œWelcome to New York,â€ Taylor Swift

Swifties will know all about Cornelia Street and how Ms. Taylor made her move to NYC in 2014. This track reflects that monumental time for her, relocating from Nashville to NYC.

5. â€œAutumn in New York,â€ Billie Holiday

Composed by Vernon Duke, â€œAutumn in New Yorkâ€ has been sung by legends such as Ella Fitzgerald, Bing Crosby, and most famously, Billie Holiday.

6. â€œNew York Groove,â€ Russ Ballard

This sing-along song was written by English musician and songwriter, Russ Ballard, but truly came to life after Bronx-born Ace Frehley from Kiss recorded it on solo album.

7. â€œNew York State of Mind,â€ Billy Joel

According to a 2010 interview with Howard Stern, Billy Joel wrote â€œNew York State of Mindâ€ in 15 minutes on an upstate-bound bus. â€œPiano Manâ€ was actually born in the Bronx but grew up on Long Island.

8. â€œLiving for the City,â€ Stevie Wonder

This song by the legend, Stevie Wonder, reflects on his move from Mississippi to New York City and the difficulties that ensued thereafter.

9. â€œRockaway Beach,â€ Ramones

The band sings an ode to Dee Deeâ€™s beloved beach escape in the big city.

10. â€œBrooklynâ€™s Finest,â€ Jay Z & Biggie Smalls

This iconic duo both got on the track to touch upon growing up in Brooklyn and how their struggles have turned to success.

11. â€œN.Y. State of Mind,â€ Nas

Nas (Nasir bin Olu Dara Jones) raps about the inescapable violence and dangers surrounding him on the streets of NYC. He was born in Crown Heights and dominated the rap game in the 90s.

12. â€œC.R.E.A.M.,â€ Wu-Tang

Standing for Cash Rules Everything Around Me, their song was inspired by a letter from an incarcerated friend referring to money as â€œcream.â€ The hip hop group hails from Staten Island and had forever changed the rap game after releasing their first album, Enter The Wu-Tang (36 Chambers).

13. â€œChelsea Morning,â€ Joni Mitchell

Supposedly Joni Mitchell was inspired by a glass mobile she had hanging in her Chelsea apartment. She explained in an interview with the Los Angeles Times the beauty of the mobile when the sun hit it, cascading colors around the room.

14. â€œThe Only Boy Living In New York,â€ Simon & Garfunkel

This track on the duoâ€™s last studio album touches on the topic of loneliness that all New Yorkers can relate to as Simon was waiting for Garfunkel to come back from shooting Catch-22 in Mexico.

15. â€œJenny From The Block,â€ Jennifer Lopez

Bronx-born actress, dancer and singer references her roots even after her rise to fame and how sheâ€™s still her genuine self behind it all. Fun fact: according to Songfacts, she references the Bronx 28 times in the track!
